UNC path to localhost. Unfortunately, we need to do some fudging with this to preserve the hostname. '\\localhost\someshare' is a valid UNC path, and Chrome, Edge, IE, etc are all able to locate it using 'file://localhost/someshare'. We need the hostname to be able to resolve the path '/someshare'; nothing on Windows seems able to resolve the host-less 'file:///someshare'. The most compatible option appears to be to use the IPv4 loopback address; '\\.\UNC\localhost\someshare' (i.e. file://./UNC/localhost/someshare) would also be an option, but IE/Explorer can't handle those.
Namespaced UNC path to localhost. Unfortunately, we need to do some fudging to maintain that this is a UNC path.
UNC path to localhost (mixed case). See above for the reason behind this unfortunate hack.
Namespaced UNC path to localhost (mixed case)

URL path, UNC with trailing percent-encoded NULL byte [with hostname]
URL path with a Windows drive-letter [no hostname, no trailing]. Windows treats this as a relative path without the trailing slash.
URL path with a Windows drive-letter [no hostname, no trailing] (lowercase)
URL path with a Windows drive-letter [no hostname, with trailing].
URL path with a Windows drive-letter [no hostname, with trailing] (lowercase)
URL path with a Windows drive-letter [with hostname, no trailing]. UNC paths are always fully-qualified, and don't really have 'drive letters' as such, so the trailing slash isn't required.
URL path with a Windows drive-letter [with hostname, no trailing] (lowercase)
URL path with a Windows drive-letter [with hostname, with trailing].
URL path with a Windows drive-letter [with hostname, with trailing] (lowercase)
URL path with a Windows drive-letter in $ notation [no hostname, with trailing]
URL path with a Windows drive-letter in $ notation [with hostname, with trailing]
URL path with a Windows drive-letter in $ notation [with hostname, with trailing] (lowercase)

URL path with a Windows drive-relative path [no hostname, with trailing].
URL path with a Windows drive-relative path [no hostname, with trailing] (lowercase)

URL path with an escaped drive-letter [no hostname, with trailing]

URL path with a Windows drive-relative path [no hostname, with trailing].

URL path with an escaped drive-letter [with hostname, with trailing]

URL path with an escaped drive-letter [no hostname, with trailing] (alt)
URL with an escaped drive letter [no hostname] (alt)(2)
URL path with an escaped drive-letter [with hostname, no trailing] (alt)
URL path with an escaped drive-letter [with hostname, with trailing] (alt)
URL encoding DOS device path. See above notes about drive letters in UNC paths
URL encoding DOS device path (alt)
URL encoding UNC path. Share name is an encoded a drive letter. Extra slashes before share name.
UNC path, share looks like a drive letter (alt). Extra slashes before share name.
URL path components with trailing dots [no hostname, no drive, no trailing]
URL path components with trailing dots [no hostname, with drive, no trailing]
URL path components with trailing dots [no hostname, no drive, with trailing]
URL path components with trailing dots [no hostname, with drive, with trailing]
URL path with trailing dot in UNC share name. Share names are never trimmed.
URL path with trailing space in UNC share name
URL path with extra slashes before UNC share name
URL path components with trailing dots [with hostname, no trailing]
UNC Path, path components with trailing dots [with hostname, with trailing]
URL with UNC share root [no trailing]
URL with UNC share root [with trailing]
URL path where final component is only dots and spaces [no drive, no trailing]
URL path where final component is only dots and spaces [with drive, no trailing]. The Windows API 'GetFullPathName' trims it all away.
URL path where final component is only dots and spaces [no drive, with trailing]
URL path where final component is only dots and spaces [with drive, with trailing]
URL with UNC path whose share name is only dots and spaces
URL with UNC path whose share name is only dots and spaces [no trailing]
URL with UNC path whose final (non share) path component is only dots and spaces [no trailing]
URL with UNC path whose final (non share) path component is only dots and spaces [with trailing]
URL path with trailing '...' component [no drive, no trailing]
URL path with trailing '...' component [with drive, no trailing]. The Windows API 'GetFullPathName' trims it all away.
URL path with trailing '...' component [no drive, with trailing]
URL path with trailing '...' component [with drive, with trailing]
URL with UNC path with '...' share name
URL with UNC path with '...' share name [no trailing]
URL with UNC path whose final (non share) path component is a '...' component [no trailing]
URL with UNC path whose final (non share) path component is a '...' component [with trailing]

URL path with 2 leading slashes [no hostname, no drive]. Posix: double slashes should be preserved in file path. Windows: unclear; some applications encode UNC paths this way (e.g. Java). For now it is rejected as a relative path on Windows.

URL path with 2 leading slashes [no hostname, with drive]. Posix: double slashes should be preserved in file path. Windows: invalid; 'GetFullPathName' never treats this as a local path, and 'C:' is not a valid hostname.
URL path with 2 leading slashes [no hostname, with drive(escaped)].
URL path with 2 leading slashes [no hostname, with drive(alt)].
URL path with 2 leading slashes [no hostname, with drive(alt, escaped)].
URL path with 2 leading slashes, between UNC host and share [with hostname]. 'GetFullPathName' on Windows trims slashes before the share name, but also trims the share name (probable bug).
URL path with 2 leading slashes, between UNC host and share [with hostname]. One is a percent-encoded backslash, which should be rejected rather than trimmed away.
URL path with 3 leading slashes [no hostname, no drive]. Should be collapsed to single slash.
URL path with 3 leading slashes [no hostname, no drive]. One is percent-encoded, which should be rejected rather than trimmed away.
URL path with 3 leading slashes [no hostname, no drive]. One is a percent-encoded backslash, which is allowed on POSIX but rejected on Windows.
URL path with 3 leading slashes [no hostname, with drive]. Should be collapsed to single slash.
URL path with 3 leading slashes [no hostname, with drive(escaped)].
URL path with 3 leading slashes [no hostname, with drive(alt)].
URL path with 3 leading slashes [no hostname, with drive(alt, escaped)].
URL path with 3 leading slashes, between UNC host and share. 'GetFullPathName' on Windows trims slashes before the share name.
URL path with 3 leading slashes, between UNC host and share. One is a percent-encoded backslash, which should be rejected rather than trimmed away.
URL path with 4 leading slashes [no hostname, no drive]. Should be collapsed to single slash.
URL path with 4 leading slashes [no hostname, no drive]. One is percent-encoded, which should be rejected rather than trimmed away.
URL path with 4 leading slashes [no hostname, no drive]. Some are percent-encoded backslashes, which are allowed on POSIX but rejected on Windows.
URL path with 4 leading slashes [no hostname, with drive]. Should be collapsed to single slash.
URL path with 4 leading slashes [no hostname, with drive(escaped)].
URL path with 4 leading slashes [no hostname, with drive(alt)].
URL path with 4 leading slashes [no hostname, with drive(alt, escaped)].
URL path with 4 leading slashes, between UNC host and share. 'GetFullPathName' on Windows trims slashes before the share name.
URL path with 4 leading slashes, between UNC host and share. One is a percent-encoded backslash, which should be rejected rather than trimmed away.
URL path with 5 leading slashes [no hostname, no drive]. Should be collapsed to single slash.
URL path with 5 leading slashes [no hostname, no drive]. One is percent-encoded, which should be rejected rather than trimmed away.
URL path with 5 leading slashes [no hostname, no drive]. Some are percent-encoded backslashes, which are allowed on POSIX but rejected on Windows.
URL path with 5 leading slashes [no hostname, with drive]. Should be collapsed to single slash.
URL path with 5 leading slashes [no hostname, with drive(escaped)].
URL path with 5 leading slashes [no hostname, with drive(alt)].
URL path with 5 leading slashes [no hostname, with drive(alt, escaped)].
URL path with 5 leading slashes, between UNC host and share. 'GetFullPathName' on Windows trims slashes before the share name.
URL path with 5 leading slashes, between UNC host and share. One is a percent-encoded backslash, which should be rejected rather than trimmed away.
URL path with extra slashes in the middle. Should be normalized to a single slash. [no drive, no hostname]
URL path with extra slashes in the middle. Should be normalized to a single slash. [with drive, no hostname]
URL path with extra slashes in the middle. Some are percent-encoded backslashes. [with drive, no hostname]
URL path with extra trailing slashes. Should be normalized to a single slash. [no drive, no hostname]
URL path with extra trailing slashes. Should be normalized to a single slash. [with drive, no hostname]
URL path with extra trailing slashes. Some are percent-encoded backslashes. [with drive, no hostname]
URL with UNC path, extra slashes before share.
URL with UNC path, extra slashes between share/path.
URL with UNC path, extra trailing slashes.
URL with query string. Should be ignored in the file path [no drive, no hostname]
URL with query string [with drive, no hostname]
URL with query string [no drive, with hostname]
URL with query string. Leading double-slashes make it look a bit like a Win32 file namespace path.
URL with fragment. Should be ignored in the file path [no drive, no hostname]
URL with query string [with drive, no hostname]
URL with query string [no drive, with hostname]
